case_vignette: A 61-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaint of sudden onset, painless vision loss in her left eye upon waking up this morning. The patient says that she had no visual abnormalities prior to the incident and has had 20/20 vision in both eyes since undergoing cataract surgery the previous year. Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. An ophthalmology consult is called, and fundoscopic examination confirms the diagnosis (Figure A).
question: Which  is the most likely cause for this patient’s vision loss?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I woke up this morning and suddenly couldn't see out of my left eye, but it doesn't hurt at all.
Have you had any vision problems before?
No, I haven't had any visual problems before this, and I had perfect vision since my cataract surgery last year.
Have you noticed any flashes of light or spots in your vision?
No, I haven't noticed any flashes of light or spots in my vision.
Have you had any headaches or dizziness?
No, I haven't had any headaches or dizziness.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or diet?
No, I haven't had any recent changes in my medication or diet.
Have you had any family history of eye conditions?
The vignette doesn't provide any information about my family history of eye conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presented to the clinic with sudden loss of vision in the left eye, without any associated pain. The patient had a cataract surgery last year and had no visual problems before this. There were no associated symptoms such as flashes of light, spots in the vision, headaches, or dizziness. There were no recent changes in medication or diet, and no family history of eye conditions was mentioned.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: The most likely cause for this patient's vision loss is Ischemic optic neuropathy.
trial_0.multiturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Central retinal vein occlusion.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most likely cause for this patient's vision loss is a complication of cataract surgery.
